notSafe.content:
This service may not be right for you if you’ve experienced domestic abuse.

Find out how to recognise domestic abuse.

Get help and advice on making child arrangements when there’s been domestic abuse.

childrenSafetyCheck.title: Children’s safety
childrenSafetyCheck.content:
Children may be at risk if there has been:

  • any form of domestic abuse or violence, even if the abuse was not directed at the children
  • actual or attempted child abduction
  • child abuse or neglect
  • misuse of drugs, alcohol or other substances
  • any other safety or welfare concerns that place anyone at significant risk of harm

childrenNotSafe.title: Getting help
childrenNotSafe.content:
It may not be appropriate to make child arrangements if there’s any risk of harm to the children.

Get advice on protecting children from abuse.

Citizens Advice has advice on making child arrangements when there’s been domestic abuse.
childrenNotSafe.feelConfident: If you feel confident that making child arrangements will not put children at risk,

doWhatsBest.title: What’s best for the children?
doWhatsBest.content:
Your child arrangements plan should reflect what is best for the children. You must consider their wants and needs when making these arrangements.

Remember, the aim is to make sure your children are as happy as they can be.
doWhatsBest.childrensNeedsFirst: I will put my children’s needs first

courtOrderCheck.title: Do you already have a court order in place about your child arrangements?
courtOrderCheck.subText: This could include a prohibited steps, specific issue or consent order.

existingCourtOrder.title: You can still use this service
existingCourtOrder.text:
If you can reach agreement with the other parent or carer, then you do not need to go back to court to change your arrangements. However, a court can only enforce the child arrangements that are in your court order.

If you have prohibited steps order or a specific issue order

Check any legal documents sent to you by a judge to see whether you have a prohibited steps order or a specific issue order (section 8).

You must not try to change any rules given to you in a prohibited steps order or specific issue order. You can only propose changes to other parts of your child arrangements, such as what day of the week your children visit you.

whichSchedule.title: Which schedule best meets the children's needs?
whichSchedule.commonSchedules:
Here are some common schedules that can benefit children.

Alternating weeks
The children will spend one week in one household and the next week in the other.

2-2-3 schedule
Children spend two days in one household, two days in the other, then back to the first house for 3 days including the weekend.

4-4-3 schedule
Children spend three days in one household then four days in the other. The next week they switch.

2-2-5-5 schedule
Children spend two days in one household, then two days in the other. After that they spend five days in one household, then five days in the other.
whichSchedule.exactSplit: An exact split of time between two households does not always suit children’s best interests.

sharePlan.sendThePlanTo: Send this proposed child arrangements plan to {{ name }}
sharePlan.content:
You've created a proposed child arrangements plan. You must now share the plan with {{ otherAdult }} to get their agreement.

What to do next

Send this proposed child arrangements plan to {{ otherAdult }}. {{ otherAdult }} will have the chance to respond.

If {{ otherAdult }} does not respond

If {{ otherAdult }} does not respond, you can try mediation. The next step would be to apply for a court order.

Find out more about what to do if you cannot agree.

whatWeAreTelling.title: What we're telling {{ name }} about this plan
whatWeAreTelling.context:
Proposed child arrangements plan for {{ childrenNames }}

{{ senderName }} is asking that you work together to come up with a plan for how to look after {{ childrenNames }}. These proposed child arrangements aim to find a way you can both work together to make {{ childrenNames }} as happy and secure as possible.

You do not need to accept what {{ senderName }} is proposing. Instead you can:

  • use this form to suggest changes to what {{ senderName }} is proposing
  • start your own proposed child arrangements plan using the propose a child arrangements plan service on GOV.UK, or by finding a similar service
  • make a written plan of your own without using any service or template

Why you should work with {{ senderName }} to make a plan

It’s best if you and {{ senderName }} work together to plan what arrangements are best for the children. If you can agree on a plan, you may be able to avoid court.
whatWeAreTelling.courtOrderInPlace:
As you have a court order in place

{{ senderName }} has told us that there is a court order in place about your child arrangements. If you can reach agreement with {{ senderName }}, then you do not need to go back to court to change your arrangements. However, a court can only enforce the child arrangements that are in your court order.

If you have prohibited steps order or a specific issue order

Check any legal documents sent to you by a judge to see whether you have a prohibited steps order or a specific issue order (section 8).
whatWeAreTelling.topTips:
Top tips

You do not need to accept what {{ senderName }} is proposing. Instead you can:

  • One of the main reasons people end up in court is that they are not willing to compromise to reach agreement. It may help you avoid court if you can work with {{ senderName }} to find a compromise that’s best for your children.
  • Get your children’s input into the arrangements you are making so that they feel included and their needs are met.
  • Remember to always put your children’s needs and feelings first.
  • It may not be in the children’s best interests to split time exactly between households.
whatWeAreTelling.moreInfo:
If you need more information about divorce and separation

Check GOV.UK to find what support is available including:

  • Separating or divorcing: what you need to do
  • Making child arrangements if you divorce or separate
  • Getting emotional support
whatWeAreTelling.safetyCheck:
Safety check

To make child arrangements you need to be able to state your needs and views without feeling intimidated. Do not continue with this process if you think the other parent is a threat to you or your children's safety.

Do not continue with this process if there has been:

  • any form of domestic abuse or violence, even if the abuse was not directed at the children
  • actual or attempted child abduction
  • child abuse or neglect
  • misuse of drugs, alcohol or other substances
  • any other safety or welfare concerns that place anyone at significant risk of harm

Instead you should find another way to make arrangements by visiting https://helpwithchildarrangements.service.justice.gov.uk

Getting help with abuse and domestic violence

To find out more about what is child abuse and neglect, visit https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-is-child-abuse

If you're unsure whether you're a victim of domestic abuse, visit https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/getting-help-for-domestic-violence
